wikipedia_page.main: David John Mordaunt (24 August 1937 – 28 November 2020) was an English cricketer, teacher and expeditioner.

response: Simons also played two List A matches for Hertfordshire. The first came in the 1964 Gillette Cup in Hertfordshire's inaugural List A match against Durham. Hertfordshire were dismissed for 63, which was at the time the lowest total made in that format. Simons was dismissed by John Bailey for 7 runs, with Durham winning by 7 wickets. His second match in that format came against Berkshire in the 1966 Gillette Cup, with him being dismissed for 7 by David Mordaunt, with Hertfordshire scoring 167 all out in their innings. Berkshire won the match by 2 wickets.

Several members of Mordaunt's family also played first-class cricket. His brothers Henry and Eustace played for Middlesex and for other teams, his father, John Mordaunt, played for MCC and his grandson David Mordaunt was a Sussex and Minor Counties cricketer in the last days of amateurism in the 1950s.

response: In April 1864, he was promoted to lieutenant in the Warwickshire Yeomanry. Mordaunt went into business with Thomas Ridley Oswald as a shipbuilder in Southampton in 1878, with the company being declared bankrupt in 1881. In addition to having served as a deputy lieutenant for Warwickshire, Mordaunt was also a justice of the peace for the county. He died at Westminster in December 1923.Obituary. Warwick and Warwickshire Advertiser. 29 December 1923. p. 4 He was married to Elizabeth Evelyn Cotes, with the couple having five children; their three sons Eustace, Gerald and Henry all played first-class cricket. Other relations who also played first-class cricket included his brother, Osbert, great-grandson David Mordaunt and nephew Francis Portman.
